title: How to turn protest into powerful change - Eric Liu

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of protest, according to the text?

options.label: A
options.text: To maintain the status quo

options.label: B
options.text: To challenge the status quo and bring about change

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore social issues

options.label: D
options.text: To criticize others without taking action

multiple-choice.question: What happened in the Middle East after the Arab Spring?

options.label: A
options.text: The dictators were replaced by democratic leaders

options.label: B
options.text: The vacuum was often filled by the most militant and violent groups

options.label: C
options.text: The people became complacent and stopped protesting

options.label: D
options.text: The economy improved significantly

multiple-choice.question: What is the first strategy for peacefully turning awareness into action and protest into durable political power?

options.label: A
options.text: Expanding the frame of the possible

options.label: B
options.text: Choosing a defining fight

options.label: C
options.text: Seeking an early win

options.label: D
options.text: Ignoring the opposition

multiple-choice.question: What does it mean to "expand the frame of the possible"?

options.label: A
options.text: To limit the scope of what can be achieved

options.label: B
options.text: To push the boundaries of what is considered possible

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore the frame of the possible remains unchanged

options.label: D
options.text: To focus on short-term gains

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of choosing a defining fight?

options.label: A
options.text: To avoid conflict

options.label: B
options.text: To create a contrast and set the terms of a debate

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore the opposition

options.label: D
options.text: To compromise on issues

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a defining fight mentioned in the text?

options.label: A
options.text: The fight for a $15 minimum wage

options.label: B
options.text: The fight for a smaller national government

options.label: C
options.text: The fight for a single-payer healthcare system

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the third key strategy for peacefully turning awareness into action and protest into durable political power?

options.label: A
options.text: Expanding the frame of the possible

options.label: B
options.text: Choosing a defining fight

options.label: C
options.text: Seeking an early win

options.label: D
options.text: Ignoring the opposition

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of seeking an early win?

options.label: A
options.text: To give up on social change

options.label: B
options.text: To create momentum and change what people think is possible

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore the opposition

options.label: D
options.text: To compromise on issues

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an early win mentioned in the text?

options.label: A
options.text: The Solidarity movement in Poland

options.label: B
options.text: The Arab Spring

options.label: C
options.text: The U.S. Civil Rights Movement

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to being part of the process of expanding the frame of the possible, choosing a defining fight, or securing an early win?

options.label: A
options.text: Being a leader or someone special

options.label: B
options.text: Being a participant and living like a citizen

options.label: C
options.text: Ignoring the opposition

options.label: D
options.text: Giving up on social change

title: Self-assembly: The power of organizing the unorganized - Skylar Tibbits

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for a system where unordered parts come together in an organized structure, completely on their own?

options.label: A
options.text: Self organization

options.label: B
options.text: Replication

options.label: C
options.text: DNA folding

options.label: D
options.text: Self assembly

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following examples exhibit self-assembly in non-biological systems?

options.label: A
options.text: Snowflakes

options.label: B
options.text: Magnets

options.label: C
options.text: Robotics

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the primary function of proteins in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide structural support

options.label: B
options.text: To fold and perform specific functions

options.label: C
options.text: To replicate DNA

options.label: D
options.text: To facilitate self-assembly

multiple-choice.question: How do proteins fold into 3-D structures, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Through random interactions

options.label: B
options.text: Through interactions between amino acids and the environment

options.label: C
options.text: Through interactions between amino acids only

options.label: D
options.text: Through external forces

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a system that self-assembles, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A sphere made up of identical pieces

options.label: B
options.text: A soccer ball

options.label: C
options.text: A protein chain

options.label: D
options.text: A virus with specific shapes that attract each other

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the advantage of using self-assembly in design and engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduces reliance on fossil fuels

options.label: B
options.text: It makes technologies more complex

options.label: C
options.text: It makes technologies easier to build and more adaptive

options.label: D
options.text: It makes technologies less reliable

multiple-choice.question: What process occurs in biology and chemistry, including atomic interactions, cellular replication, and DNA, RNA, and protein folding, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Self organization

options.label: B
options.text: Replication

options.label: C
options.text: DNA folding

options.label: D
options.text: Self assembly

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what are some potential applications of self-assembly in the future?

options.label: A
options.text: Making materials that can repair themselves

options.label: B
options.text: Making water pipes that can reconfigure on demand

options.label: C
options.text: Making buildings that can adapt to environmental changes

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the ultimate goal of using self-assembly in design and engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: To create technologies that are more complex and less reliable

options.label: B
options.text: To create technologies that are easier to build and more adaptive

options.label: C
options.text: To create a better world

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce reliance on fossil fuels

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is an analogy for how factories and construction sites could be designed using self-assembly?

options.label: A
options.text: Factories as machines and construction sites as assembly lines

options.label: B
options.text: Factories as brains and construction sites as gardens

options.label: C
options.text: Factories as organisms and construction sites as ecosystems

options.label: D
options.text: Factories as factories and construction sites as warehouses

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the benefit of cognitive diversity in a team when it comes to tasks like problem-solving and coming up with creative ideas?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to a reduction in the number of ideas generated.

options.label: B
options.text: It results in a smaller team size.

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to a massive uplift in collective intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on the outcome.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result when a group of cognitively homogeneous people work together to come up with ideas?

options.label: A
options.text: They generate a large number of unique ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a massive uplift in collective intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: They only come up with a limited number of ideas that are similar to each other.

options.label: D
options.text: They work more efficiently.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when people are surrounded by others who think in the same way as them, especially in complex tasks?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more confident in their solutions.

options.label: B
options.text: They become more open to new ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: They experience no uplift in collective intelligence and may become more confident about a potentially incorrect solution.

options.label: D
options.text: They become less confident in their solutions.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key feature of competitive advantage for the next 50 years?

options.label: A
options.text: Cognitive homogeneity.

options.label: B
options.text: Collective intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: Complexity.

options.label: D
options.text: Innovation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's opinion on the idea that if one truly believes their model is the best, they should work with people who think like them?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a compelling argument.

options.label: B
options.text: It is spectacularly wrong.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a neutral perspective.

options.label: D
options.text: It is irrelevant.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what happens when people mirror each other's perspectives?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more confident in their solutions.

options.label: B
options.text: They experience a massive uplift in collective intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: They become more confident about a solution that might be gravely mistaken.

options.label: D
options.text: They become less confident in their solutions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of cognitive diversity in a team when it comes to complex tasks?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to a reduction in the number of ideas generated.

options.label: B
options.text: It results in a smaller team size.

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to a massive uplift in collective intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on the outcome.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why are people attracted to others who think like them?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it validates their world view.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is more efficient.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is more effective.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is more fun.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when people are surrounded by others who think in the same way as them, and the complexity of the task increases?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more confident in their solutions.

options.label: B
options.text: They become more open to new ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: They experience no uplift in collective intelligence and may become more confident about a potentially incorrect solution.

options.label: D
options.text: They become less confident in their solutions.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the tragedy of cognitive diversity?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to a reduction in the number of ideas generated.

options.label: B
options.text: It results in a smaller team size.

options.label: C
options.text: It is often overlooked, despite its potential to lead to a massive uplift in collective intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on the outcome.
